outputs.content:
# MAJOR GIFT PROPOSAL

**Pacific Coastal Conservancy Alliance**
1450 Embarcadero Drive, Suite 300
San Francisco, CA 94133
www.pccalliance.org

December 18, 2025

Ms. Patricia Winters, Executive Director
Mariner Bank Foundation
800 Harbor Boulevard
San Francisco, CA 94111

Dear Ms. Winters,

Your CSR team joined 120 community volunteers last spring at the Pt. Pinole planting day; many were employees' families learning how native cordgrass protects neighborhoods from storm surges. At Pacific Coastal Conservancy Alliance, we restore and protect West Coast ecosystems while advancing community resilience and equitable access to nature—values I know resonate deeply with Mariner Bank Foundation's commitment to climate resilience, thriving coastal communities, skilled workforce pathways, and meaningful corporate volunteerism.

At Pt. Pinole, your employees planted thousands of sedge and cordgrass plugs beside local teens earning restoration stipends. That shared effort is exactly the partnership we hope to deepen. Today, I invite you to consider a leadership investment in our Coastal Wetlands Restoration & Resilience Initiative—a five-year effort to restore 80 acres of living shorelines, protect 2,400 homes from flooding, and train 100 community members for green careers across the San Francisco Bay shoreline and Sonoma Coast.

Thank you for your continued partnership. I look forward to exploring this opportunity together.

Warmly,

[SIGNER NAME, TITLE]
Pacific Coastal Conservancy Alliance
lena.cho@pccalliance.org | 415-555-9021

---

## Donor Alignment

Mariner Bank Foundation's strategic priorities align powerfully with the Coastal Wetlands Restoration & Resilience Initiative:

• **Climate resilience:** This project restores tidal marshes and living shorelines that absorb wave energy, sequester carbon, and buffer Richmond, Vallejo, and coastal communities against storm surges intensified by sea-level rise—exactly the nature-based infrastructure your 2024 Climate Adaptation Grant portfolio champions.

• **Coastal communities:** We focus on frontline neighborhoods in Richmond and Vallejo where 68% of residents identify as communities of color and median household income falls 30% below the regional average; your Foundation's 2023 Equitable Recovery Fund demonstrated commitment to these same populations.

• **Workforce development:** Our Community Restoration Training Program provides paid stipends, safety certifications, and job placements for local residents—many facing barriers to employment—mirroring your multi-year investment in vocational pathways for underserved youth.

• **Corporate volunteerism:** Your spring 2025 Pt. Pinole planting day engaged 45 Mariner Bank employees and families in hands-on habitat restoration; this Initiative offers quarterly volunteer opportunities, technical skill-building days, and co-hosted community science events to deepen employee engagement and environmental stewardship.

---

## Project Overview

**What:** The Coastal Wetlands Restoration & Resilience Initiative will restore 80 acres of tidal wetlands and living shorelines across six priority sites in San Francisco Bay (Richmond, Vallejo, Pt. Pinole) and the Sonoma Coast over five years. We will re-grade degraded marshlands, plant 240,000 native sedges and cordgrass plugs, install bio-swales and oyster reefs, and establish long-term water-quality and biodiversity monitoring. Simultaneously, our Community Restoration Training Program will equip 100 local residents—including young adults, career-changers, and formerly incarcerated individuals—with paid restoration work experience, OSHA and wetland-delineation certifications, and pathways to green jobs in habitat management, environmental consulting, and climate adaptation.

**Why now:** The NOAA National Coastal Resilience Fund offers a 1:1 match up to $2,000,000 for private gifts committed by March 31, 2026, effectively doubling the impact of early leadership investments. Meanwhile, San Francisco Bay has lost 90% of its historic tidal marshes, leaving shoreline communities increasingly vulnerable; the 100-year floodplain now encompasses 2,400 homes in our project footprint. State and federal permits for our six sites were finalized in August 2025, enabling us to break ground in spring 2026.

**Who benefits:** This Initiative directly serves 2,400 households in Richmond and Vallejo's shoreline neighborhoods and 100 trainees enrolled in our workforce program. Trainees range in age from 18 to 55; 72% identify as Black, Latinx, or Pacific Islander; 40% face barriers including prior justice involvement, housing instability, or gaps in formal education. Restored wetlands will also benefit migrating shorebirds along the Pacific Flyway and enhance public access for 15,000 annual visitors to our shoreline trail network.

**How we deliver:** Our restoration follows a proven four-phase model: (1) community input sessions to refine site designs; (2) earthwork and grading by licensed contractors; (3) planting and bioengineering led by trained community crews; (4) three years of adaptive monitoring using tide gauges, vegetation transects, and eDNA sampling. Workforce trainees complete 400 hours over six months, earning $7,500 stipends plus certifications, mentorship from habitat professionals, and job-placement support.

**Equity and access:** We schedule training cohorts on weekends and evenings to accommodate working parents and caregivers. Stipends remove financial barriers to participation. All restoration sites include ADA-accessible boardwalks, multilingual interpretive signage, and free public programming in English, Spanish, and Tagalog.

**Risks and mitigations:** *Risk:* Delayed permit modifications due to regulatory review timelines. *Mitigation:* We maintain a portfolio of six permitted sites, allowing us to shift resources to shovel-ready locations if one encounters delays. *Risk:* Trainee attrition before program completion. *Mitigation:* Peer cohort model, case-management support for housing and transportation needs, and partnerships with employers who commit to interview graduates.

---

## Budget & Request

**Total project cost:** $15,000,000  
**Raised to date:** $9,800,000  
**Funding gap:** $5,200,000

**We invite you to consider a gift of $2,500,000 over five years** ($500,000 annually, 2026–2030). Your investment would fund the restoration of 30 acres of priority wetlands in Richmond and Vallejo, support 40 workforce trainees through our six-month program, and sustain monitoring infrastructure at two key sites.

**Pledge schedule:**
- Year 1 (2026): $500,000  
- Year 2 (2027): $500,000  
- Year 3 (2028): $500,000  
- Year 4 (2029): $500,000  
- Year 5 (2030): $500,000

**Leverage opportunity:** The NOAA National Coastal Resilience Fund will match eligible private gifts 1:1 up to $2,000,000 if committed by March 31, 2026. A $2,500,000 pledge would unlock the full $2,000,000 federal match, magnifying your impact to $4,500,000 in combined resources.

**Alternative gift levels:**

- **$1,500,000 over five years** ($300,000 annually) would enable complete restoration of 50 acres at a priority site and fund community workforce training for 24 trainees, including stipends, certifications, and job-placement services.

- **$4,000,000 over five years** ($800,000 annually) would enable us to scale to an additional 30 acres beyond our current plan and extend adaptive monitoring from three to five years, capturing long-term ecosystem response and informing best practices for Bay-wide marsh restoration.

**What your investment buys:**

- $30,000 restores one acre of tidal wetlands (earthwork, native plants, monitoring).
- $7,500 funds one community trainee in habitat restoration (stipend, PPE, certifications).
- $120,000 installs a tide gauge and water-quality monitoring station.

---

## Outcomes & Measurement

We will track progress using rigorous, transparent metrics reported biannually:

**1. Habitat restoration**  
- *Outcome:* Acres of functional tidal wetland restored.  
- *Baseline (2025):* 120 acres restored by PCCA since 2018.  
- *Target (2030):* +80 acres restored through this Initiative (200 acres cumulative).  
- *Data source:* GIS habitat maps; aerial imagery; vegetation surveys by Coastal Resilience Lab at San Francisco State University.  
- *Reporting:* Biannually via dashboard showing acreage completed, native plant survival rates, and photo documentation.

**2. Flood risk reduction**  
- *Outcome:* Reduce modeled flood exposure for nearby households.  
- *Baseline (2025):* 2,400 homes within the 100-year floodplain in project footprint; current annual flood damages estimated at $8.2 million.  
- *Target (2030):* 10% modeled reduction in annual flood damages ($820,000) in target zones, protecting infrastructure and lives.  
- *Data source:* NOAA and USGS hydrologic modeling; independent review by Estuary & Ocean Science Center.  
- *Reporting:* Biannually with updated flood-risk maps and community-impact narratives.

**3. Workforce outcomes**  
- *Outcome:* Community trainees complete the program and secure employment in environmental fields.  
- *Baseline (2025):* 38 trainees completed certificates since 2022; 68% job-placement rate within six months.  
- *Target (2030):* 100 trainees complete the program; 75% placed in green jobs or advanced education within six months.  
- *Data source:* Participant database tracking completion, certifications earned, and employment outcomes; validated by third-party evaluator.  
- *Reporting:* Biannually with participant stories, employment data, and wage outcomes.

**4. Biodiversity indicators**  
- *Outcome:* Increase native species richness and abundance.  
- *Baseline (2025):* Average 12 native plant species per transect; shorebird counts average 340 individuals during winter surveys.  
- *Target (2030):* Average 18 native plant species per transect; shorebird counts increase 25% to 425 individuals, reflecting improved foraging habitat.  
- *Data source:* Vegetation transects; eBird data; eDNA water sampling.  
- *Reporting:* Biannually with biodiversity dashboards and interpretive summaries.

**5. Community engagement**  
- *Outcome:* Increase public access and environmental literacy.  
- *Baseline (2025):* 6,800 annual visitors to restoration sites; 220 residents participated in volunteer events.  
- *Target (2030):* 15,000 annual visitors; 800 residents engaged in volunteer restoration, community science, or educational programs.  
- *Data source:* Trail counters; event sign-in logs; post-event surveys.  
- *Reporting:* Biannually with engagement summaries and participant feedback.

---

## Timeline & Milestones

**Year 1 (2026):**  
- Q1 (Jan–Mar): Finalize partnership agreements; launch workforce recruitment in Richmond and Vallejo; secure NOAA match by March 31 deadline.  
- Q2 (Apr–Jun): Break ground at Pt. Pinole North (15 acres); onboard first cohort of 20 trainees; install two tide-gauge stations.  
- Q3 (Jul–Sep): Complete grading and bioengineering at Pt. Pinole North; plant 60,000 native plugs with trainee crews and corporate volunteers.  
- Q4 (Oct–Dec): Graduate first trainee cohort; initiate restoration at Vallejo Marina site (12 acres); publish Year 1 impact dashboard.

**Year 2 (2027):**  
- Q1–Q2: Restore Vallejo Marina site; recruit and train second cohort (20 trainees); establish monitoring transects.  
- Q3–Q4: Begin Sonoma Coast pilot (8 acres); adaptive planting based on Year 1 survival data; host joint thought-leadership convening on living shorelines.

**Year 3 (2028):**  
- Q1–Q2: Complete Richmond shoreline segment (18 acres); third trainee cohort (20 participants); midpoint evaluation by SFSU.  
- Q3–Q4: Expand Sonoma Coast work (10 additional acres); publish peer-reviewed outcomes; update flood-risk models.

**Years 4–5 (2029–2030):**  
- Restore remaining 27 acres across priority sites; train final two cohorts (40 trainees total); conduct five-year ecological assessments; finalize long-term stewardship agreements with local agencies; celebrate project completion with donor recognition event.

---

## Recognition

We would be honored to recognize Mariner Bank Foundation's leadership through:

- **Naming of a living shoreline segment:** The "Mariner Bank Foundation Living Shoreline" at Pt. Pinole North or another priority site, with interpretive signage explaining the wetland's role in climate resilience and community protection.

- **Signage at restoration sites:** Donor acknowledgment on trailhead kiosks and educational panels at all six project sites, visible to 15,000 annual visitors.

- **Media and annual report:** Recognition in press releases, PCCA's annual impact report (distributed to 8,500 supporters), website donor spotlight, and social media celebrating the partnership.

- **Joint thought-leadership events:** Co-hosted convenings on nature-based climate solutions, inviting Mariner Bank executives, coastal scientists, policymakers, and community leaders to share insights and advance regional resilience strategies.

Corporate recognition is encouraged, but we fully honor your preference for anonymity if desired. All recognition options are flexible and designed in partnership with your communications team to align with your institutional goals and values.

---

## Co-Design & Engagement

Your insights would strengthen this work. We invite Mariner Bank Foundation to provide input on:

- **Site prioritization:** Among our six permitted locations, which geographies or community demographics should receive earliest investment—Richmond's historically underserved shoreline neighborhoods, Vallejo's industrial waterfront transitioning to public access, or Sonoma Coast's rural communities?

- **Workforce program emphasis:** Should evaluation prioritize job-placement rates, wage gains, participant skill confidence, or long-term career retention? Your perspective on workforce outcomes would help us refine metrics that matter most.

- **Learning agenda:** What questions about nature-based infrastructure, community co-benefits, or corporate engagement models would you like this Initiative to explore and share with peers in the financial sector committed to climate action?

We propose **quarterly learning sessions with your ESG team**—virtual or in-person site visits—to review data, troubleshoot challenges, and share stories from trainees and community members. Additionally, we invite you to seat a representative on our **Corporate Partners Council**, a forum for peer exchange and strategic input on program evolution. This is a genuine partnership; your expertise in community investment and climate risk will make the Initiative more effective and more accountable.

---

## Stewardship & Reporting

**Who reports:** Lena Cho, Director of Philanthropy, will serve as your primary contact, supported by Project Director Miguel Santos for technical updates and trainee stories.

**Cadence:** You will receive **biannual reports** (June and December) throughout the five-year pledge period.

**Format:** Each report includes:
- Financial statement showing funds received, expenditures by budget category, and restricted-fund balance.
- Narrative update on restoration progress, workforce outcomes, and community engagement.
- Visual dashboard with maps, photos, and key metrics (acres restored, trainees graduated, biodiversity indicators).
- At least two participant or community stories illustrating impact.

**Engagement opportunities:**
- Annual site visit (in-person or virtual) to walk restored wetlands, meet trainees, and observe monitoring in action.
- Invitation to volunteer planting days, trainee graduation ceremonies, and public celebration events.
- Mid-project impact briefing (Year 3) with SFSU evaluators to review findings and adaptations.

We are committed to transparency, learning, and partnership. If challenges arise—permitting delays, slower recruitment, or ecological setbacks—we will communicate promptly and collaboratively problem-solve.

---

## Governance & Approvals

The Coastal Wetlands Restoration & Resilience Initiative project plan and budget were approved by Pacific Coastal Conservancy Alliance's Board of Directors on September 12, 2025. All restricted gifts are held in segregated accounts and tracked through our Salesforce grants-management system. PCCA is audited annually by Kline & Ross, LLP; our most recent audit (FY 2024) resulted in an unqualified opinion with no material findings. We maintain reserves equivalent to four months of operating expenses and a diverse funding portfolio spanning federal grants (38%), foundation support (42%), and individual donors (20%). Financial statements and IRS Form 990 are available at www.pccalliance.org/financials.

---

## Next Steps

I would welcome the opportunity to discuss this proposal with you by **December 18, 2025**, or at your earliest convenience. Whether you have questions about site selection, workforce pathways, matching-fund mechanics, or recognition options, I am here to listen and collaborate.

Please contact me directly:

**Lena Cho, Director of Philanthropy**  
lena.cho@pccalliance.org | 415-555-9021  
Pacific Coastal Conservancy Alliance  
www.pccalliance.org  
1450 Embarcadero Drive, Suite 300  
San Francisco, CA 94133

Thank you for your partnership in restoring the ecosystems that protect our communities, sustain biodiversity, and build a more resilient coast. Together, we can create living shorelines that shelter homes, nurture wildlife, and open pathways to meaningful careers—exactly the future we envision for the Bay and beyond.

With gratitude and anticipation,

**[SIGNER NAME, TITLE]**  
Pacific Coastal Conservancy Alliance  
lena.cho@pccalliance.org | 415-555-9021

---

*Pacific Coastal Conservancy Alliance is a 501(c)(3) nonprofit organization. Tax ID: 94-1234567. All contributions are tax-deductible to the fullest extent of the law.*
